intro: Pedicularis macrosiphon, commonly known as the large-lipped lousewort, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its lack of chlorophyll, making it a hemiparasitic plant. The plant has fleshy, often hairy stems and produces showy, spurred flowers that range in color from pink to purple. It thrives in moist, shaded habitats and is often found in alpine meadows and forested areas. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
